items.title: Gaza peace plan hinges on Hamas decision after Trump, Netanyahu back deal
items.summary: Mediators from Qatar and Egypt shared the document with Hamas, which was not involved in negotiations in the lead-up to the 20-point plan.

items.title: Decision to allow registered nurses to prescribe medicines solves many health service problems
items.summary: Tens of thousands of registered nurses across the country will be able to up-skill to prescribe medications usually authorised by a doctor. It's a reform that could change the medical landscape in Australia... and the lives of many patients.

items.title: RBA holds fire; energy stock sell-off
items.summary: Despite solid gains by the gold miners, a sell-off in energy stocks – fuelled by a continued decline in oil prices – has dragged the Australian sharemarket. For more, Stephanie Youssef spoke with Jonathan Shead, Head of Investment at State Street Investment Management. Plus, the Reserve Bank left interest rates unchanged at 3.6 percent, as expected, at its September board meeting. For more, Stephanie Youssef spoke with Pradeep Philip from Deloitte Access Economics.

items.title: 'The pinnacle': One of Australia's most dominant teams aims at 40-year record
items.summary: Australia's women's cricket side take on New Zealand in their first World Cup match.

items.title: Optus faces backlash over triple-zero failures, with calls for consequences
items.summary: A meeting between Communications Minister Anika Wells and leaders from Optus and its parent company, Singtel, has yielded little new information or action. It comes as calls for stronger consequences grow in the wake of multiple triple-zero failures that have been linked to deaths. Critics say there's more the minister could be doing right now to restore public trust.

items.title: The PM's new supermarket proposal might cut your bills, but it's 'no silver bullet'
items.summary: The prime minister needs to consider preconditions, such as space and a break-up of Coles and Woolworths, if he wants a competing supermarket to thrive and bring down prices.

items.title: The Reserve Bank keeps interest rates on hold | Evening News Bulletin 30 September 2025

items.summary: A United States proposal for peace in Gaza has received endorsement from Israel and the Palestinian Authority, but its long-term success is on a knife-edge.

items.title: New guidelines developed for helping people with dementia
items.summary: A framework has been developed to track and improve the treatment options for dementia patients in aged care. The proposal come after the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare named dementia as the leading cause of death in Australia.

items.title: Middle East peace talks: US, Israel propose plan as Hamas weighs response
items.summary: Israel and the United States have agreed to a plan for ending the war in Gaza. But both US President Donald Trump and Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu have indicated if Hamas rejects the plan, the militant group will face the consequences. Hamas says it is reviewing the proposals.

items.title: Vital role of translators celebrated amid AI challenge
items.summary: It's been eight years since the United Nations first recognised International Translation Day. The celebration falls on 30 September and recognises the work of language professionals who foster cultural understanding, connection and social cohesion. But some translators and interpreters in Australia believe more needs to be done to protect the workforce and bridge language barriers.

items.title: The hidden form of sexual assault you may not know about
items.summary: Stealthing — the removal of a condom during sex without a partner's knowledge or consent — is criminalised in most of Australia. But experts warn many people remain unaware of what it is and the risks it poses.

items.title: The effects of Tonga's massive volcanic explosion linger, three years on
items.summary: It's been more than three and a half years since one of the most powerful volcanic eruptions in recent history left devastation in Tonga. An Australian-led scientific team has been studying the area surrounding the underwater volcano, in collaboration with researchers from across the world, looking for signs of life. The eruption changed the shape of the sea floor and devastated the underwater environment but early signs of life are beginning to emerge.

items.title: MSF suspends Gaza City health activities as Hamas denies reports of an in-principle truce
items.summary: Hamas has contradicted a prominent Israeli newspaper's report that it had agreed in principle to a truce deal proposed by the US president.

items.title: INTERVIEW: 'We are family, we should work together': Palau President's challenge to Australia
items.summary: Palau, an independent island nation in the western Pacific Ocean, consists of more than 300 islands in Micronesia. It's a popular destination for divers and ecotourists and visitors are required to take the "Palau Pledge" to protect its ecosystems. But Palau is already facing the immediate reality of climate change, with rising sea levels, coral bleaching, extreme weather events, and biodiversity loss. Surangel Whipps Junior, the President of Palau, has spoken at the United Nations General Assembly in New York, and wants to see the COP31 global climate conference held in the Pacific region rather than in Turkiye, because this is where climate change is already having devastating impacts. He's been talking to SBS Senior International Correspondent Ben Lewis, and told him that Palau and Australia are family - and the two countries need to work together.

items.title: Republican Albanese meets the King, as Opposition questions taxpayer bill for UK trip
items.summary: Sussan Ley has struck out at Anthony Albanese attending a UK Labour Party conference, saying he isn't in the UK as ALP leader. The prime minister said he has important ministerial meetings at the conference, and he's also met with the UK Opposition leader.

items.title: INTERVIEW: Footballer Fandi Ahmad is a Singaporean sporting legend: We find out why
items.summary: Fandi Ahmad is more than just a footballer; has been described as a national legend in Singapore. He was the first Singaporean footballer to play in Europe, the first Singaporean millionaire sportsperson and the first Singaporean sportsperson to have a published biography. As a young child, his family lived in a two-room public housing flat, Fandi was obsessed with football and spent much of his time kicking a ball. He became arguably Asia's best known footballer. He's shared the pitch with Diego Maradona, and was picked to play for Dutch football giant Ajax - an offer he subsequently turned down. Fandi's Muslim faith is central to his life. He avoids scandals, does not smoke or drink, and has been described as humble, filial, and compassionate. In this extended edition of Weekend One on One, he talks to SBS's Christopher Tan

items.title: 'Jekyll and Hyde': How to win over Australia's most polarising bird

items.title: Optus to pay $100m fine for sales practices targeting vulnerable Australians
items.summary: Amid Optus' triple-zero outage crisis, the Federal Court has added to the company's woes after approving a $100 million penalty for "appalling and predatory" conduct in the telco's sales practices.

items.title: Higher inflation threatens rate cuts & is the US market overvalued?
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Paul Bloxham from HSBC about today's stronger than expected inflation figures and what it means for interest rates, plus the day on the sharemarket with Francesco De Stradis from Ord Minnett.

items.title: President Trump's extraordinary address at the UN General Assembly
items.summary: Donald Trump has stunned the United Nations, using his speech at the General Assembly to suggest other countries are “going to hell” because of migration and denying science by calling climate change a ‘con’. In an extraordinary address, he slammed the UN for not doing enough to end wars. The US President also said he’d support NATO countries shooting down a Russian aircraft that breaches their airspace, and declared Kyiv can win back ‘all of Ukraine’.

items.title: Three-year inflation high could mean 'wafer-thin' chance of interest rate cut pre November
items.summary: Freshly released inflation data will prompt the Reserve Bank to keep the cash rate on hold in September, but a cut in November is still "very much on the cards", experts say.

items.title: Aboriginal people report less respectful hospital care. Here's what can make a difference
items.summary: More than a quarter of Aboriginal patients said there had been a time in the past year they needed to go to hospital but didn't, a report has found.

items.title: NT hit-and-run case spotlights deep disparities in criminal justice system, advocates say
items.summary: The Northern Territory has been engulfed by significant backlash regarding the sentencing of a driver who fatally struck an Aboriginal man in a hit and run and his familial connection to the Territory's Attorney General. First Nations communities and legal experts argue the sentence given to Jake Danby, a 12-month community corrections order, is inconsistent with the 'tough on crime' approach of the Country Liberal Party government.

items.title: Donald Trump walks his own path on autism research. Health experts say claims don't stack up
items.summary: US President Donald Trump has announced his administration will direct doctors not to recommend paracetamol for pregnant women, claiming it may be linked to autism in children. Australian medical experts have responded, re-confirming that paracetamol is safe for use in pregnancy.

items.title: 150-plus countries now recognise Palestine - what does it mean and could it impact the war?
items.summary: Australia has joined 150-plus countries who now officially recognise a Palestinian state. But after nearly two years of war in Gaza, and a death toll in excess of 65,000, what would a state of Palestine even look like? Is this recognition purely symbolic, or does it have real-world implications? And could it help bring an end to the conflict?

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 24 September 2025
items.summary: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

items.title: Super Typhoon Ragasa: Cyclone bears down on southern China after 17 killed in Taiwan
items.summary: Millions of people in southern China are in Typhoon Ragasa's sights after the most powerful cyclone of 2025 battered Hong Kong and killed 17 people in Taiwan.

items.title: Super Typhoon Ragasa: Cyclone bears down on southern China after 17 killed in Taiwan
items.summary: Millions of people in southern China are in Typhoon Ragasa's sights after the most powerful cyclone of 2025 battered Hong Kong and killed 17 people in Taiwan.

items.summary: Millions of people in southern China are in Typhoon Ragasa's sights after the most powerful cyclone of 2025 battered Hong Kong and killed 17 people in Taiwan.

items.title: Countries 'going to hell' and other key takeaways from Donald Trump's UN speech
items.summary: Trump warned that migration is sending Western nations "to hell" and dismissed climate change as a "con job".

items.title: These girls are only able to study in secret. For many, their 'last hope' is being taken away
items.summary: With a new internet ban in the north of Afghanistan in force, members of the diaspora in Australia worry their families will be even more isolated.

items.title: Australian doctors describe 'slaughterhouse' in Gaza hospital as medicine runs out
items.summary: Two Australian doctors volunteering in one of Gaza's last functioning hospitals say nothing prepared them for what they have witnessed in the past two weeks.

items.title: Third time's a charm? Albanese and Trump meeting confirmed for next month
items.summary: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has finally locked in a formal face-to-face meeting with Donald Trump, after a number of false starts.

items.title: Third time's a charm? Albanese and Trump meeting confirmed for next month
items.summary: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has finally locked in a formal face-to-face meeting with Donald Trump, after a number of false starts.

items.title: Are your blueberries safe? Why a pesticide scare has some concerned
items.summary: Pesticide suspended after tests on store-bought berries found high levels of harmful chemicals.

items.title: Nvidia's huge OpenAI deal, and Myer's profit tumbles
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Michael McCarthy from MooMoo Australia about the day's market action including Myer's disappointing profit result, and Nvidia's huge OpenAI deal.

items.title: The states and territories where renters have it the best — and worst
items.summary: Two years after a national pledge to deliver a 'Better Deal for Renters', a new report finds progress remains uneven — with rights still dictated by postcode.

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 23 September 2025
items.summary: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

items.title: France joins Australia and others in recognising a Palestinian state at the UN General Assembly
items.summary: France has formally recognised the state of Palestine in what President Emmanuel Macron hailed as a historic step towards Middle East peace. The decision, welcomed by Palestinian leaders and backed by several allies, set the tone for the United Nations' 80th anniversary session, even as Israel and the United States condemned it and boycotted proceedings.

items.title: Albanese uses UN speech to call on Israel to 'accept responsibility' over Gaza 'catastrophe'
items.summary: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has called for an Israeli-Palestinian two-state solution at a high-level address at the UN General Assembly.

items.title: Albanese uses UN speech to call on Israel to 'accept responsibility' over Gaza 'catastrophe'
items.summary: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has called for an Israeli-Palestinian two-state solution at a high-level address at the UN General Assembly.

items.title: Albanese uses UN speech to call on Israel to 'accept responsibility' over Gaza 'catastrophe'
items.summary: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has called for an Israeli-Palestinian two-state solution at a high-level address at the UN General Assembly.

items.title: Albanese uses UN speech to call on Israel to 'accept responsibility' over Gaza 'catastrophe'
items.summary: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has called for an Israeli-Palestinian two-state solution at a high-level address at the UN General Assembly.

items.title: Qantas warns of flight disruptions as Typhoon Ragasa approaches Hong Kong
items.summary: Thousands of people have been evacuated in the northern Philippines as one of the strongest typhoons this year threatens to cause flooding and landslides.

items.title: UK charities end links with Prince Andrew's ex-wife over Epstein email
items.summary: In a 2011 email to convicted US sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, the ex-wife of disgraced Prince Andrew, Sarah Ferguson, said she considered him a "supreme friend" and apologised for publicly disowning him.

items.title: 'A uniquely delicate crime': Dangers of stealthing poorly understood by Australians
items.summary: Stealthing, the removal of a condom during sex without a partner's knowledge or consent, has in recent years become a criminal offence in almost all parts of Australia. But experts say there is still a lack of awareness about what stealthing is and the dangers it poses.

items.title: Why many Australians don't feel financially confident & ASX rises as market waits for US inflation
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Luke McMillan from Ophir Asset Management about the day's sharemarket action while Stephanie Youssef looks through the latest AMP research with Ben Hillier which reveals half of Australians don't feel financially confident as they approach retirement.

items.title: Why Brooke chose Facebook over an IVF clinic to find a sperm donor
items.summary: As demand for sperm donors increases, some are avoiding fertility clinics in favour of less formal networks. Meanwhile, for donors, there is a range of ethical considerations and potential unintended consequences to consider.

items.title: Albanese in New York: Will the PM finally meet Trump — and what happens if he doesn't?
items.summary: The prime minister has wasted no time since arriving in the Big Apple. What lies ahead?

items.title: Are more interest rate cuts on the cards?
Australia recognises Palestinian state at the UN
items.summary: Australia has joined Canada, Portugal and the United Kingdom in formally recognising a Palestinian state at the UN. The declaration was made by Prime Minister Anthony Albanese and Foreign Minister Penny Wong outside the United Nations headquarters in New York City, with the government saying it comes as part of a push for a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has issued a warning to the countries, while saying he aims to ensure there will never be a Palestinian state.

items.title: Simone was a loyal Optus customer. Then her husband needed an ambulance
items.summary: Hundreds of calls to triple-zero failed to connect during an Optus network outage linked to three deaths.

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 22 September 2025
items.summary: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

items.title: The penalties Optus could face after its 'second significant and egregious failure'
items.summary: The Australian Communications and Media Authority has announced its investigation into the Optus triple-zero outage, with the communications minister warning there will be consequences for the sector.

items.title: Some Australians are not confident about their retirement. Here's how much you need a year
items.summary: Australians looking for work in their 40s and women, especially those divorced or single with children, are not feeling confident about retirement.

items.title: 'Remarkable': How Gaza protests unfolded in Australia and around the world
items.summary: Australia is considered a "low protest country" but it has held some of the biggest pro-Palestinian protests in the world. Explore how Gaza protests have unfolded in our interactive map.

items.title: 'Disgraceful': Optus launches investigation, reveals two more emergency call failures
items.summary: Optus says alongside an investigation, it will launch a new compulsory escalation process following any customer reports of 000 failures.

items.title: A cyber attack has hit some of Europe's busiest airports. Here's what you need to know
items.summary: The cyber attack on check-in systems caused cancellations and long delays for thousands of passengers.

items.title: Republicans warn Australia of 'punitive measures' recognising Palestinian statehood
items.summary: Anthony Albanese will recognise Palestinian statehood along with other world leaders at the UN General Assembly this week.

items.title: At least 60 Palestinians killed as Israel presses on with Gaza City assault
items.summary: The Israeli military estimates it has demolished up to 20 Gaza City tower blocks over the past two weeks.

items.title: Here's the tea: Global shortage means steep prices for matcha lovers
items.summary: Global matcha prices are surging due to poor weather in Japan, rising global demand, labour shortages, and steep US tariffs on imports from Japan and China. Now, the world’s love affair with matcha may be tested - at the checkout counter.

items.title: White House issues clarification after Trump hits H-1B visas with $150,000 fee
items.summary: The announcement sparked concerns among employees across swaths of corporate America.

items.title: Opinions divided on how to save our precious mountain ash forests
items.summary: New research has found Australia's heat-stressed forests are rapidly thinning, and could even be producing carbon emissions. It comes as the government prepares to release its 2035 emissions targets and a climate risk report later this month. But local researchers, politicians and Traditional Owner land groups remain divided on how to protect the forest.

items.title: The UN has reached a historic milestone. The world will be watching what it does next
items.summary: This week's United Nations meeting will be a landmark occasion for multiple reasons.

items.title: 'Not exactly glamorous': The 'disheartening' reality of dating in rural Australia
items.summary: Rural Australians say dating in the country is a whole lot harder than in the city, with geographic isolation the least of their worries. Finding someone with the same values and lifestyle priorities is often the hardest challenge, which is why singles events in the sticks are having such a big impact.

items.title: The 'quite simple' way this group of Australians could save lives
items.summary: Australians receiving treatment for "urgent" and "critical" diseases are having to wait for people overseas to make life-saving donations.

items.title: Why some Australian parents are giving their kids as much as $200k
items.summary: Parents and grandparents are increasingly offering financial assistance to family members with 20 per cent saying they provided help in the last quarter.

items.title: Jess Hull breaks Australian record and qualifies for 800m final at World Athletics Championships
items.summary: The 28-year-old recorded a time of 1:57.15 and placed third in her semi-final heat in Tokyo on Friday night.

items.title: The 80th General Assembly of the UN is meeting in New York. How does it work - and why?
items.summary: World leaders will gather in New York next week for the annual General Assembly. Secretary-General Antonio Guterres has highlighted peace, climate, responsible innovation, gender equality, development financing and UN reform as central themes of the week. But the high-level week of the General Assembly also marks the 80th anniversary of the founding of the United Nations. We take a look at just what the UNGA is and what its powers are.

items.title: I feel like privacy is dead: IVF data breach triggers interest in class action lawsuit
items.summary: After years of trying to conceive, Isabel Lewis thought the hard part was over — until cybercriminals targeted her fertility clinic. The data breach at Genea Fertility included patient's medical histories, diagnoses and treatments, medications and prescriptions, as well as pathology and diagnostic test results. Now, hundreds of Australians have shown interest in a class action lawsuit over the breach, which could be the first test of new reforms to Australia's Privacy Act.

items.title: 'Incredibly tragic event': Fourth death linked to 10-hour Optus triple-zero outage
items.summary: South Australian Premier Peter Malinauskas blasted the telco's slow and "bewildering" response, vowing it would be held to account for the outage that affected approximately 600 triple-zero calls.

items.title: 'Incredibly tragic event': Fourth death linked to 10-hour Optus triple-zero outage
items.summary: South Australian Premier Peter Malinauskas blasted the telco's slow and "bewildering" response, vowing it would be held to account for the outage that affected approximately 600 triple-zero calls.

items.title: Healing land and spirit through Noongar knowledge and regenerative land management
items.summary: In Western Australia's Wheatbelt, a region long shaped by industrial farming practices, a new model of regenerative agriculture is taking root. At Yaraguia farm, Ballardong Noongar man Oral McGuire is healing Country, reconnecting First Nations knowledge of caring for Country with modern land management to restore ecosystems and produce food that benefits both the land and the community.

items.title: Free speech fears continue to roil US as Trump says unfair media coverage is 'illegal'
items.summary: What began as a late-night joke has spiralled into a test of free speech in Trump’s America.

items.title: 'Really angry': Isabel is one of hundreds considering class action against this IVF provider
items.summary: Hundreds of Australians have shown interest in a class action lawsuit, which could be the first test of new reforms to Australia's Privacy Act.

items.title: Three people dead after Optus network upgrade sparked triple-zero call failure
items.summary: Two of the deceased were from South Australia and one from Western Australia, Optus CEO Stephen Rue said.

items.title: Age pension to rise & is AI in bubble territory?
items.summary: Stephanie Youssef speaks with Omkar Joshi from Opal Capital Management for the day's sharemarket news, including whether AI is in bubble territory, while SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves goes through the upcoming age pension changes with Joshua Parisotto from HESTA.

items.title: 'Right plan for Australia': Government ministers defend 2035 climate target
items.summary: Climate advocates say the federal government's 2035 emissions reduction target falls "dangerously short", while the Coalition has said its plan is "grounded in fantasy land". Government ministers are now working to justify the target to the public and the community, as the Coalition is under pressure to outline their climate policy.

items.title: What we know about Charlie Kirk's memorial service
items.summary: Charlie Kirk, a right-wing political commentator, was assassinated while speaking at a university campus in the US state of Utah last week.

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 19 September 2025
items.summary: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

items.title: The Aussie dollar is having a moment. Here's what it means for you
items.summary: The Australian dollar is trading at around a 10-month high against the US dollar and has been broadly performing "very well". But it's not the whole story, experts say.

items.title: Gout Gout is out of the World Athletics Championships — but time is on his side
items.summary: The 17-year-old placed fourth in the second semi-final on Thursday night with a time of 20.36 seconds.

items.title: Foreign policy, free speech and Epstein: Takeaways from Trump and Starmer's press conference
items.summary: The US and UK leaders hailed the renewal of the countries' "special relationship" as Trump's state visit drew to a close.

items.title: Trump's royal treatment, UN declares 'genocide' in Gaza & Albania's AI minister
items.summary: Donald Trump gets some face time with the King & Queen on a state visit to the UK. A UN commission of inquiry finds Israel’s war in Gaza amounts to genocide as Israel’s ground operation in Gaza City gets underway. MAGA vows war on the left in response to Charlie Kirk's killing and Bolsonaro is sentenced to 27 years in jail. Plus, Albania unveils an all AI minister.

items.title: The $500 million problem caused by an 'out-of-date' super rule
items.summary: One part of Australia's superannuation system has been "frozen for years" — and its a problem that could be leaving some shortchanged, according to a new report.

items.title: Full-time jobs tumble, US cuts rates & future of chocolate prices
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Blair Chapman from Seek about the latest jobs data which showed a near 41,000 fall in full-time jobs; Lochlan Halloway from Morningstar takes a look at the day's sharemarket action including the reaction to the US Federal Reserve's first interst rate cut this year; and Stephanie Youssef discusses the future of chocolate prices with Paul Joules from Rabobank.

items.title: Too high or too low? Australia's 2035 climate target pleases no one
items.summary: As one of the world's biggest greenhouse gas emitters per capita, Australia has announced its new 2035 emissions reduction target. The federal government has committed to a target to cut emissions by 62 to 70 per cent by 2035, based on 2005 levels. Some say the target is too high, others say it's too low. Labor says it's both ambitious and achievable.

items.title: 'Not likely to please anyone': Labor's 'ambitious' new emissions target faces criticism
items.summary: The updated target has been criticised as both insufficient and overly ambitious.

items.title: Donald Trump says he's designating Antifa as 'major terrorist organisation'
items.summary: The crackdown on left-wing groups follows last week's assassination of right-wing commentator and Trump ally Charlie Kirk.

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 18 September 2025
items.summary: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.
